channel.title: Fruit on jzhao.xyz
channel.description: Recent content in Fruit on jzhao.xyz

item.title: From Legibility to Identity
item.description: What is identity? Who defines it? Who controls it? What is its relationship to software? Software developers and computer scientists have been tackling identity for almost half a century now, trying to model identity in ways that are understandable to machines.

item.title: Towards Data Neutrality
item.description: This essay was originally published in Reboot. DISCLAIMER: To borrow words from Robin Sloan: While it is okay to share this link, I want to underscore that I am sending it specifically to you with the hope that you will really think about it!

item.title: Open Source and Politics
item.description: [[thoughts/Coraline Ada Ehmke|Coraline Ada Ehmke]] is an acclaimed speaker, writer, engineer, and activist with over 25 years of experience in software and almost 20 years in open source.

item.title: Hold the Fries
item.description: “Shaun, you’re doing that thing again. Staring into some far off land. Hurry up loopyhead, figure out what you wanna get.

item.title: Casual Magic
item.description: A small collection of poetry about magic in the everyday casual magic At 1:00, the sun streamed at just the right angle through the patterned glass, splitting the uniform beam of light into a hidden spectrum of fractals, bathing the room in a shower of brilliant colours.

item.title: PHIL240A Final Paper
item.description: Section I: Trusting Institutions Is it ever responsible to trust an institution about something that outstrips your individual ability to verify?

item.title: On Consciousness
item.description: ![[thoughts/images/consciousness-midjourney.png]]“Bridging the explanatory gap from the other side” @midjourney An exploration into the [[thoughts/philosophy of science|philosophy of science]]. What is consciousness even?

item.title: Nothing stops
item.description: It was so heavy-handed and so stupid, hitting the nail on the head so hard that it rang like a bell.

item.title: Bias in Search
item.description: Term paper for INFO303 One of the critiques of search engines is a lack of transparency and potential for bias in their algorithms.

item.title: Consciousness is not Information
item.description: Paper #2 for PHIL 451A Prompt 1: Is consciousness essentially a kind of information? When we examine theories of consciousness, we find that we can divide the majority of theories into two major categories: process theories and vehicle theories1.

item.title: Indra's Paradox
item.description: CRWR 200 Short Story Disclaimer: This piece touches on suicidal ideation. My intention was to explore the connection of the Buddhist conception of emptiness and the experience of death/non-being.

item.title: Search Diary
item.description: Entry 1 Day, Time, and Location: February 6th, ~4:01pm EST, Montreal How long did the search take? ~10 seconds Photo showing setting of the search: No photo, but was sitting at a desk with a couple of friends!

item.title: The Dragon and the Bridge
item.description: Paper #1 for PHIL240A at UBC It’s been three weeks now since you woke up deep in a forest. You’ve managed to survive; the forest itself isn’t that bad.

item.title: Pace Layers
item.description: The order of civilization. The whole combines learning with continuity. Coined by Stewart Brand in 1999. See: [[thoughts/Mangrove Theory of the Internet|Mangrove Theory of the Internet]], [[thoughts/Bentoism|Cross-time-scale planning (Bentoism)]]

item.title: World Building
item.description: Emissaries Guide To Worlding James Stuber’s Blog Well-built worlds enable new stories. Games and fiction are forms of worldbuilding (or ‘worlding’ as Cheng says), but not the only ones

item.title: Me, my selves, and I
item.description: An exploration on commitment, trust, and growth. The Persistence of Memory by Salvador Dalí The sound of the waves are nice, huh?

item.title: Trust as Unquestioning Attitude
item.description: PHIL240A Essay 1 Explain how Nguyen’s account of trust as an unquestioning attitude entails that we integrate objects into our own agency.

item.title: A Letter to my Past and Future selves
item.description: Have you been writing those letters to yourself? “Dear Evan Hansen, This is gonna be a good day and here’s why.

item.title: A New Glossary of Words
item.description: This is an expansion of thoughts on terminology and why we need new words. The following is a dialogue on the original consensus problem: agreeing on what we mean.

item.title: Play to Win: A Post-Work Society
item.description: Extension of my thoughts about play and discussions from our Interact Circle on Hackathon Culture and Play. Defining play I’ve spent a lot of the past few months reminiscing on the childhood days of finding funny looking patterns in the rocks in my backyard and building LEGOs without instruction manuals.

item.title: React in 30 minutes
item.description: React is, as the website says, “a JavaScript library for building user interfaces.” What this means exactly, is often confusing to people.

item.title: Networked Thought
item.description: “Gardens … lie between farmland and wilderness … The garden is farmland that delights the senses, designed for delight rather than commodity.

item.title: Hacking the Hackathon
item.description: The ‘Involution’ of Hackathons A late night breakthrough on our PennApps XX Project “Quick, quick, Caden! Wake up – the drone is flying!

item.title: The bookstore with a single book, knowledge distillation, and tight feedback loops
item.description: I am writing this newsletter edition as NYC is being bombarded by hail. The sounds of little balls of ice ricocheting off of the roof has a sort of din to it that feels oddly comforting?

item.title: Framing and Context Collapse
item.description: The content I throw on Twitter is not something I would readily post on LinkedIn. I also wouldn’t post LinkedIn-style business content to my Facebook timeline.

item.title: Sun sneezing, infrastructure moderation, and why bikes are better than tricycles
item.description: Hello there and welcome back to another issue of some mildly coherent ramblings. It’s been yet another couple busy weeks, but I’ve just wrapped up my second decade on this crazy planet!

item.title: Rewriting ctrl-v using Next.js
item.description: Ever since I released ctrl-v, friends from HackClub have kept bugging me about switching my current React code over to use Next.

item.title: A case for funding Open Source
item.description: Making of Open Source software I’ve recently made my way through Working in Public: The Making and Maintenance of Open Source Software by Nadia Eghbal.

item.title: Spider-man neurons, hearing fractals, and fulfilment
item.description: I can’t believe we’re approaching a time of year when I can wait until after dinner to turn on my desk light.

item.title: A request for coffee chats
item.description: This month of January went by with blazing speed. I can’t say if it’s because of school starting back up or just the massive amounts of s t u f f going on in the world right now.

item.title: Digital Gardening
item.description: As of 2021, this process is no longer accurate. I’ve embraced a much more networked form of note taking which I’ve written about here.

item.title: Hello world!
item.description: Hi there and thanks for signing up for my newsletter! I’ll try to keep these in a rough 3-2-1 fashion in each issue, with 3 things I’ve found interesting from others, 2 things I’ve been wondering about, and 1 thing I’ve done.

item.title: 2020: An Imperfect Palindrome
item.description: A year of ‘almosts’ 2020 is: about 9.5 times longer than a Rick Roll in seconds about 54 times longer than the number of minutes I listened to Spotify this year about how many contributions I made on GitHub this year roughly the amount of pages I’ve read this year almost a palindrome Now there’s nothing super fascinating about almost-palindromes but it is also very fitting given the number of ‘almosts’ in my year.

item.title: Collaborative Thinking
item.description: Recently, I’ve been reading 21 Lessons for the 21st Century written by none other than Yuval Noah Harari, and have been enjoying the book.

item.title: Machines and Intelligence
item.description: This blog post is adapted from a term paper I wrote for PHIL250: Minds and Machines at UBC. I hope you enjoy the post and learn as much as I did in writing it!

item.title: On AI's 'Bias Bug'
item.description: This blog post was originally intended to be a TED Talk given at TEDxRedmond but I unfortunately was never accepted. However, I did learn a lot in the process of writing it, and I hope you get some value out of it even its presented through just text.

item.title: Docker Explained
item.description: Content from my own ‘Docker Explained’ repo. Check out the repository for example code! Introduction What is Docker? Docker is a tool that makes it really easy to package applications into self-sustaining ‘containers’.

item.title: reflect: NLP Model Explained
item.description: How do we tell that this is a “valid” intent? A (not so) brief exploration of how we tackle classifying intents in reflect.

item.title: Interning at Hootsuite in Highschool
item.description: (with insights from Calvin and Hobbes) Since I’ve started at Hootsuite, I have added and/or changed 6223 lines of code in 16 different repos
